background: Scene: Chandler and Joey's, night. Chandler and Joey are sharing the sofabed in the living room. Joey is restless.

lines.dialogue: Hey, Kicky. What're you doing?
Just trying to get comfortable. I can't sleep in my underwear.
Well, you're gonna.
I've been thinking. Y'know, about how I'm always seeing girls on top of girls...
Are they end to end, or tall like pancakes?

Y'know what I mean, about how I'm always going out with all these women. And I always figured, when the right one comes along, I'd be able to be a stand-up guy and go the distance, y'know? Now I'm looking at my dad, thinking...
Hey, you're not him. You're you. When they were all over you to go into your father's pipe-fitting business, did you cave?
No.

No. You decided to go into the out-of-work actor business. Now that wasn't easy, but you did it! And I'd like to believe that when the right woman comes along, you will have the courage and the guts to say "No thanks, I'm married."
You really think so?
Yeah. I really do.
Thanks, Chandler. (Snuggles up to him)
Get off!

summary: In this scene, Joey and Chandler are sharing the sofabed at Chandler and Joey's apartment. Joey is having trouble sleeping and is restless. He expresses his concern about his inability to stay committed to one woman, reflecting on his father's example. Chandler reassures Joey, reminding him of his past decisions to pursue his acting career despite the pressure to follow in his father's footsteps. Chandler encourages Joey to believe in his ability to commit when the right woman comes along. Joey appreciates Chandler's support and snuggles up to him, but Chandler quickly tells him to get off.

background: Scene: Chandler and Joey's, the next morning. Joey is getting the door in his dressing gown—it's Ross.

lines.dialogue: Hey, is Chandler here?
Yeah.

Okay, uh, about last night, um, Chandler.. you didn't tell... (Joey shakes his head) Okay, 'cause I'm thinking- we don't need to tell Chandler, I mean, it was just a kiss, right? One kiss? No big deal? Right?
Right. No big deal.
Okay.
In Bizarro World!! You broke the code!
What code?
You don't kiss your friend's mom! Sisters are okay, maybe a hot-lookin' aunt... but not a mom, never a mom!
What are you guys doing out here?
Uh.. uh.. Well, Joey and I had discussed getting in an early morning racquetball game. But, um, apparently, somebody overslept.
Yeah, well, you don't have your racket.
No, no I don't, because it's being restrung, somebody was supposed to bring me one.
Yeah, well you didn't call and leave your grip size.
Okay, you guys spend waaaay too much time together. (Goes back inside and shuts the door)
Okay, I'm scum, I'm scum.
Ross, how could you let this happen?
I don't know, God, I... well, it's not like she's a regular mom, y'know? She's, she's sexy, she's...
You don't think my mom's sexy?
Well... not in the same way...
I'll have you know that Gloria Tribbiani was a handsome woman in her day, alright? You think it's easy giving birth to seven children?
Okay, I think we're getting into a weird area here...
Hey.
Hey.
What're you guys doing out here?
Well, not playing raquetball!
He forgot to leave his grip size!
He didn't get the goggles!
Well,sounds like you two have issues.
Goodbye, baby.
Ciao, bela.
Do they wait for me to do this?
So are you gonna tell him?
Why would I tell him?
How about 'cause if you don't, his mother might.
Oh...
(Entering) What are you guys doing here?
Uhhhh.... he's not even wearing a jockstrap!
...What did I ask?

summary:
In this scene, Ross is at Joey and Chandler's apartment, trying to keep a secret from Chandler. He had kissed Chandler's mom the previous night and is worried about Chandler finding out. Joey agrees to keep it a secret but reminds Ross that it's against the "code" to kiss a friend's mom. The conversation becomes awkward and defensive when Chandler comes out, and Ross and Joey quickly make up a story about planning to play racquetball.

Later, Rachel and Paolo, who are in a relationship, share a goodbye kiss, which Ross awkwardly observes. Joey pressures Ross about whether he will tell Chandler the truth, but Ross is hesitant, especially since Chandler's mom might reveal it herself. The scene ends with Monica entering and questioning what they are doing, to which Joey gives a nonsensical answer about not wearing a jockstrap.

background: Scene: Hospital. Phoebe is there stroking Coma Guy's hair, when Monica enters with a bunch of balloons.

lines.dialogue: Hi.
Hi.
What are you doing here?
Nothing, I just thought I'd stop by.. y'know, after the uh... that I.. y'know, so what are you doing here?
I'm not really here. Just thought I'd drop these off...on the way.. my way... Do you come here a lot? Without me?
No. (Monica brushes Coma Guy's hair in the other direction) No! No! ...So, um, do you think he's doing any better than he was this morning?
How would I know? I-I wasn't here.
Really? Not even to, um, change his PAJAMAS?! (Whips back the sheet to reveal him wearing new pajamas.)

summary:
In this scene, Phoebe and Monica are at the hospital visiting Coma Guy. Phoebe is gently stroking Coma Guy's hair when Monica enters with a bunch of balloons. Monica asks Phoebe what she's doing there, and Phoebe awkwardly responds, trying to cover her tracks. Monica pretends she's not really there, just dropping off the balloons on her way somewhere else.

Phoebe denies coming to visit Coma Guy without Monica, but Monica playfully brushes his hair in the opposite direction, implying she knows more than she's letting on. Phoebe then awkwardly changes the subject, asking if Monica thinks Coma Guy is doing better, to which Monica feigns ignorance, claiming she wasn't there. Phoebe playfully accuses Monica of changing Coma Guy's pajamas, revealing that he's wearing new ones, which Monica doesn't deny.

The scene ends with a light-hearted exchange, hinting at a playful rivalry or secret between the two friends.

background: Scene: The fancy restaurant, Angela has her hand in Bob's shirt, and Monica is very uncomfortable.

lines.dialogue: Something went wrong with Underdog, and they couldn't get his head to inflate. So anyway, um, his head is like flopping down Broadway, right, and I'm just thinking... how inappropriate this is. Um, I've got something in my eye, uh, Joey, could we check it in the light, please?
Oh my god.
What?
Hello! Were we at the same table? It's like... cocktails in Appalachia.
Come on, they're close.
Close? She's got her tongue in his ear.
Oh, like you've never gotten a little rambunctious with Ross.
Joey, this is sick, it's disgusting, it's, it's—not really true, is it?
Well, who's to say what's true? I mean...
Oh my god, what were you thinking?
All right, look, I'm not proud of this, ok? Well, maybe I am a little.
(hits him lightly) Oh!
Ow!
(leaving) I'm outta here.
Wait, wait, wait. You want him, I want her. He likes you.
Really?
Yeah. I'm thinking, if we put our heads together, between the two of us, we can break them up.

summary:
In this scene, Monica and Joey are at a fancy restaurant where Angela and Bob are being very affectionate, making Monica uncomfortable. Monica tries to distract herself by talking about a malfunctioning Underdog balloon, but she eventually expresses her disgust at Angela and Bob's behavior, comparing it to "cocktails in Appalachia." Joey defends their actions, suggesting that Monica has been similarly "rambunctious" with Ross in the past. Monica dismisses this, calling the situation "sick" and "disgusting."

Joey admits he's not entirely proud of the situation but seems to enjoy it a little. Monica, frustrated, decides to leave, but Joey stops her, proposing a plan to break up Angela and Bob. He suggests that Bob likes Monica, and if they work together, they could separate the couple. Monica seems intrigued by the idea.

background: Scene: Chandler and Joey's, Chandler is seated, and the apartment is filled with baskets of fruit. Joey enters, check in hand.

lines.dialogue: Seven hundred bucks!
Alright, you did it! Do we have any fruit?
Man, hell of a two weeks, huh? Y'know what, though? I really feel like I learned something.
Really? So, you're gonna stick with this 'it's all for her' thing?
What, are you crazy? When a blind man gets his sight back, does he walk around like this? (Joey closes his eyes and walks around with arms spread.)

summary: In this scene, Joey excitedly tells Chandler that he earned $700, celebrating their success. Chandler humorously asks if they have any fruit, referencing the abundance of fruit in the apartment. Joey reflects on the experience, saying he feels like he learned something, but Chandler teases him about sticking to the "it's all for her" mindset. Joey dismisses the idea, using a comedic analogy about a blind man regaining his sight to imply that he won't keep up the act. The scene ends with their playful banter.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Monica is talking to her father.

lines.dialogue: I was just thinking. When my time comes-
Dad!
Listen to me! When my time comes, I wanna be buried at sea.
You what?
I wanna be buried at sea, it looks like fun.
Define fun.
C'mon, you'll make a day of it! You'll rent a boat, pack a lunch...
...And then we throw your body in the water... Gee, that does sound fun.
Everyone thinks they know me. Everyone says 'Jack Geller, so predictable'. Maybe after I'm gone, they'll say 'Buried at sea! Huh!'.
That's probably what they'll say.
I'd like that.

summary: In this scene, Monica is talking to her father, Mr. Geller, at their apartment. Mr. Geller casually brings up his desire to be buried at sea when he passes away, much to Monica's surprise and discomfort. He explains that he wants to be buried at sea because it seems like a fun and unconventional way to be remembered, breaking away from the usual expectations people have of him. Monica humorously responds, but ultimately goes along with his quirky request, acknowledging that it would indeed be a memorable and unique way for him to be remembered.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Rachel is dusting. She comes to the table, lifts all the magazines and wipes under them, then just puts them down again. Monica bursts in, obviously drunk.

lines.dialogue: Yo- hooo!
Where the hell've you been?
Monica and I just crashed an embassy party.
Are you drunk?!
Noooo! (Comes closer and whispers) I'm lying. I am so drunk.
Oh God, oh. Great, Monica, y'know what, you could've called, I have been up here, I've been worried...
Monica? Monica!
Water rules!
Yes, yes, it does. Okay, look, the restaurant called, they wanna know if you're gonna be showing up for work?
Nope. Going to the Big Apple Circus today.
Okay Monica, what are you doing? You're gonna lose your job! This is not you!
No, it is me! Y'know, I'm not just the person who needs to fluff the pillows and pay the bills as soon as they come in! Y'know, when I'm with her, I am so much more than that. I'm- I'm Monana!
Hello? Yes, she is, hold on a second, please. Monana, it's for you, the credit card people.
Helloooo? Yeah. Oh my God. Thanks.
What?
They've arrested Monica.

summary: In this scene, Rachel is cleaning the apartment when Monica, clearly intoxicated, bursts in after crashing an embassy party. Rachel expresses concern about Monica's behavior and whereabouts, but Monica brushes it off, admitting she's drunk and unapologetic. Rachel then informs Monica that her restaurant called, asking if she's coming to work, but Monica dismisses the idea, saying she's going to the circus instead. Rachel worries that Monica is jeopardizing her job, but Monica insists that this wild behavior is part of who she really is, introducing herself as "Monana." The scene ends with a call from the credit card company, informing Monica that "Monica" has been arrested, leaving Rachel stunned.

background: Scene: Phoebe's Massage Parlor, Phoebe's assistant is telling her about the changes to her schedule.

lines.dialogue: We've got a couple changes in your schedule. Your 4
Ok, thanks. (assistant leaves, then walks back in)
Oh, here comes your 3
Buon Giorno, Bella Phoebe!
Oh, Paolo, hi, what are you doing here?
Uh, Racquela tell me you massage, eh?
Well, Racquela's right, yeah!
Oh, okay, I don't know what you just said, so let's get started.
Uh, I am, uh, being naked?
Um, that's really your decision, I mean, some people prefer, you know, to take off...oh whoops! You're being naked!

summary: In this scene, Phoebe is at her massage parlor when her assistant informs her about some changes to her schedule. The assistant then mentions that Phoebe's next client, Paolo, is arriving. Paolo enters and greets Phoebe enthusiastically, mentioning that Racquela (likely a mutual acquaintance) told him about Phoebe's massage services. Phoebe is initially confused by Paolo's broken English but decides to proceed with the massage. Paolo, misunderstanding the situation, begins to undress, much to Phoebe's surprise. The scene ends with Phoebe awkwardly acknowledging that Paolo is indeed naked.

background: Scene: The Emergency Room, Ross is still going on about his first night with Carol.

lines.dialogue: I remember the moonlight coming through the window- and her face had the most incredible glow.
Yes, the moon, the glow, the magical feeling, you did this part- Could I get some painkillers over here, please?
He's right, enough, already. What is the big deal about today? So you slept with her for the first time, so what? You slept with her for seven years after that.
Look, it's just a little more complicated...
Well, what? What? What is it? That she left you? That she likes women? That she left you for another woman that likes women?
Little louder, okay, I think there's a man on the twelfth floor in a coma that didn't quite hear you...
Then what?
My first time with Carol was... (He mumbles the last part)
What?
It was my first time.
With Carol? (Ross gives him a look.) Oh.
So in your whole life, you've only been with one—(He gets a look too)—oh.
Whoah, boy, hockey was a big mistake! There was a whole bunch of stuff we could've done tonight!

summary:
In this scene, Ross is reminiscing about his first night with Carol, describing the romantic details of the moonlight and her glowing face. Chandler, annoyed by Ross's constant reminiscing, sarcastically interrupts, asking for painkillers and pointing out that Ross and Carol were together for seven years after that night. Joey joins in, questioning the significance of the memory.

Ross tries to explain that it's more complicated, leading Chandler to mockingly list the reasons Carol left Ross, including her sexual orientation and her relationship with another woman. Ross jokingly asks Chandler to speak louder so that a man in a coma on the twelfth floor can hear.

When pressed further, Ross reveals that his first time with Carol was also his first time ever. Both Joey and Chandler are shocked by this revelation, with Joey exclaiming that they could have done something else instead of hockey that night. The scene ends with the friends processing this surprising piece of information about Ross's past.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Ross, Chandler, and the girls are dividing some Chinese takeout, while the sitcom Family Matters is playing on the TV.

lines.dialogue: It’s not just that she’s cute, okay. It’s just that... she’s really really cute.
It doesn’t matter. You don’t dip your pen in the company ink.
Ross, your little creature’s got the remote again.
Marcel, Marcel, give Rossie the remote. Marcel. Marcel, you give Rossie the remote right now... Marce... you give Rossie the remote...
Great.
Relax, I’ll fix it.
(Looking at the television) Cool... "Urkel" in Spanish is "Urkel."
(looking at the remote) How did he do this?
(Looking out at the balcony) So tell me something, is leaving the Christmas lights up part of your plan to keep us merry all year long?
Ah no, you see, someone was supposed to take them down around New Year’s... but obviously someone forgot.
Well, someone was supposed to write "Rach, take down the lights" and put it on the re... frigerate... (finally noticing Monica’s note stuck to the refrigerator) How long has that been there?
Hey, where you been?
I went back to Riff’s. I think Ursula likes me. All I ordered was coffee, she brought me a tuna melt and four plates of curly fries.
Score.
She is so hot!
Yeah, listen. Okay, before you do anything Joey-like, you might wanna run it by err... (he indicates Phoebe, who is helping Ross understand the remote control.)
Pheebs?
(Jumping up) Yeah?
You think it would be okay if I asked out your sister?
Why? Why would you wanna... do that?  Why?
So that if we went out on a date, she’d be there.
Well, I mean, I’m not my sister’s, you know, whatever, and um... I mean, it’s true, we were one egg, once, but err, you know, we’ve grown apart, so, um... I don’t know, why not? Okay.
Cool, thanks.
You okay?
Yeah I’m fine.
You wanna watch Laverne y Shirley?

summary:
In this scene, the group is gathered at Monica and Rachel's apartment, eating Chinese takeout and watching *Family Matters* on TV. Chandler is talking about a cute coworker, and Ross warns him against getting involved with someone from work, using the phrase "don't dip your pen in the company ink." Meanwhile, Ross is trying to get Marcel, his pet monkey, to give him the remote control. Rachel notices that the character "Urkel" is called "Urkel" in Spanish, which amuses her.

Chandler points out that the Christmas lights are still up, and Monica explains that someone forgot to take them down. Rachel realizes there was a note on the refrigerator reminding her to do it. Joey reveals that he went back to Riff's, a diner, and thinks Ursula (Phoebe's twin sister) likes him because she gave him extra food. Chandler advises Joey to check with Phoebe before pursuing Ursula, which Joey does. Phoebe is initially confused but eventually gives her approval, though she seems a bit unsure.

The scene ends with Ross asking Phoebe if she wants to watch *Laverne & Shirley*, showing that the group is still casually hanging out and enjoying each other's company.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, late at night Monica is still examining her bill as Rachel emerges from her room.

lines.dialogue: Oh, Monica. You are not still going over that thing.
This woman's living my life.
What?

She's living my life, and she's doing it better than me! Look at this, look. She buys tickets for plays that I wanna see. She, she buys clothes from stores that I'm intimidated by the sales people. She spent three hundred dollars on art supplies.
You're not an artist.
Yeah, well I might be if I had the supplies! I mean, I could do all this stuff. Only I don't.
Oh, Monica, c'mon, you do cool things.
Oh really? Okay, let's compare, shall we.
(Yawning) Oh, it's so late for 'Shall we'...
Do I go horseback riding in the park? Do I take classes at the New School?
(Yawning) Nooo...
This is so unfair! She's got everything I want, and she doesn't have my mother.

summary: In this scene, Monica is obsessing over a woman's lifestyle, comparing it to her own and feeling inadequate. She points out that the woman does all the things she wishes she could do, like attending plays, shopping at intimidating stores, and spending money on art supplies. Rachel tries to comfort her by saying she does cool things too, but Monica insists on comparing their lives, listing activities she doesn't do, like horseback riding or taking classes. Monica concludes that the woman has everything she wants but doesn't have to deal with her mother, highlighting her frustration and envy.

background: Scene: Central Perk, Rachel is at the counter, serving coffee to Phoebe.

lines.dialogue: So Pheebs, what do you want for your birthday?
Well, what I really want is for my mom to be alive and enjoy it with me.
Okay... Let me put it this way. Anything from Crabtree and Evelyn?
Ooh! Bath salts would be nice.
Ooh, okay... good.
What is this place?
Look, you’re cold, I have to pee, and... (indicating the sign) ..there’s a cup of coffee on the window. How bad could it be?
I think we have an answer.
What’s she doing here?
This could be God’s way of telling us to eat at home.
Think she got fired at Riff’s?
No, no, no. We were there last night. She kept... (shuddering at the memory) ..bringing swordfish. (Indicating the ladies’ bathroom) are you gonna go to the, um?
I’m gonna wait till after we order. It’s her, right.
It looks like her.
Um, excuse me.
Yeah?
Hi, it’s us.
(Smiling blankly) Right, and it’s me.
So, so you’re here too?
Much as you are.
(Without moving her lips) Your turn.
Err... we know what we want.
(Philosophically) Oh, that’s good.
All we want is two Caffe Lattes.
And some biscotti cookies.
Good choice.
Definitely her.
Yeah.

summary: In this scene, set at Central Perk, Rachel is chatting with Phoebe about her birthday wishes. Phoebe initially expresses a heartfelt desire for her mother to be alive, but then settles on bath salts from Crabtree and Evelyn as a more practical gift. Meanwhile, Jamie and Fran enter the coffee shop, clearly uncomfortable and surprised to see Phoebe there. They exchange awkward greetings, with Jamie and Fran expressing their reluctance to be there. Fran mentions that they were at a restaurant the previous night where Phoebe was working, and the experience was unpleasant. Despite their discomfort, they order two Caffe Lattes and biscotti cookies from Phoebe. The scene ends with Jamie and Fran confirming that the person serving them is indeed Phoebe, and they seem to be resigned to their situation.

background: Scene: Carol and Susan's, Carol is reading, Ross is talking to her stomach.

lines.dialogue: And everyone's telling me, you gotta pick a major, you gotta pick a major. So, on a dare, I picked paleontology. And you have no idea what I'm saying, because, let's face it, you're a fetus. You're just happy you don't have gills anymore.
Look, you don't have to talk to it. You can sing to it if you want.
Oh, please. I am not singing to your stomach, ok?
Hi, how's it goin?
Shh! (singing) Here we come, walkin' down the street, get the funniest looks from, everyone we meet. Hey, hey! (to Carol) Hey, uh, did you just feel that?
I did.
Does it always, uh--?
No, no that was the first.
Keep singing! Keep singing!
(singing) Hey, hey, you're my baby, and I can't wait to meet you. When you come out I'll buy you a bagel, and then we'll go to the zoo.
I felt it!
(singin) Hey, hey, I'm your daddy. I'm the one without any breasts.

summary: In this scene, Ross is at Carol and Susan's apartment, and he is talking to Carol's stomach, addressing the baby inside. He humorously explains how he chose his major in paleontology on a dare, and jokes about the baby not understanding him because it's still a fetus. Carol suggests that Ross could sing to the baby instead of talking, but Ross initially refuses. However, when Susan arrives, Ross starts singing a playful, improvised song to the baby. The baby responds with a kick, which both Carol and Susan feel, prompting them to encourage Ross to keep singing. The scene ends with Ross continuing his humorous song, addressing the baby and emphasizing his role as the "daddy" without any breasts. The interaction is light-hearted and filled with humor, highlighting Ross's excitement and nervousness about becoming a father.

background: Scene: Iridium, Monica is working as Frannie enters.

lines.dialogue: Hey, Monica!
Hey Frannie, welcome back! How was Florida?
You had sex, didn't you?
How do you do that?
Oh, I hate you, I'm pushing my Aunt Roz through Parrot Jungle and you're having sex!  So? Who?
You know Paul?
Paul the Wine Guy? Oh yeah, I know Paul.
You mean you know Paul like I know Paul?
Are you kidding? I take credit for Paul. Y'know before me, there was no snap in his turtle for two years.

summary: In this scene, Monica is working at Iridium when her friend Frannie enters. Frannie immediately accuses Monica of having had sex, which Monica confirms. Frannie, who was busy pushing her Aunt Roz through Parrot Jungle in Florida, is jealous and demands to know who Monica was with. Monica reveals it was Paul, a mutual acquaintance. Frannie claims to know Paul well, even joking that she "took credit" for reviving his interest in dating after a two-year dry spell. The scene ends with Frannie's playful teasing and Monica's admission about her romantic encounter with Paul.

background: Scene: Ross's Apartment, continued from earlier.

lines.dialogue: So, Phoebs owes $7.50, Monica, you owe $10, and Rachel, you owe fifteen big ones.
But hey, thanks for teachin' us Cross-Eyed Mary. You guys, we gotta play that at our regular game.
Alright, here's my $7.50. (Hands them the money) But I think you should know that this money is cursed.
What?
Oh, I cursed it. So now bad things will happen to he who spends it.
That's alright, I'll take it. Bad things happen to me anyway. This way I can break 'em up with a movie.
Well, that just leaves the big Green poker machine, who owes fifteen...
Mmm-hmmm. Oh, so typical. Ooo, I'm a man. Ooo, I have a penis. Ooo, I have to win money to exert my power over women. (hands over her money)

You know what? This is not over. We will play you again, and we will win, and you will lose, and you will beg, and we will laugh, and we will take every last dime you have, and you will hate yourselves forever.
Hmm. Kinda stepped on my point there, Mon.

summary: In this scene, the group is settling up after a poker game at Ross's apartment. Ross collects the money owed by Phoebe, Monica, and Rachel, with Rachel owing the most. Phoebe playfully warns that her money is cursed, but Chandler jokingly accepts it, saying bad things already happen to him. Rachel sarcastically comments on Ross's "manly" victory, and Monica vows revenge, promising to beat Ross in future games and take all his money. Rachel teases Monica for interrupting her earlier point. The scene ends with the group's usual mix of humor and playful rivalry.

background: Scene: Ross' apartment, Girl, You'll Be A Woman Soon (the original, not that cruddy Urge Overkill version) is playing. Ross and Celia are kissing passionately.

lines.dialogue: Talk to me.
OK.... um, a weird thing happened to me on the train this morning...
No no no. Talk... dirty.
(embarrassed) Wha... what, here?
Yes...
Say something..... hot.
(panicked) Er.... um.....
What?
Um... uh.... vulva.

summary: In the scene, Ross and Celia are in Ross's apartment, passionately kissing while the song "Girl, You'll Be A Woman Soon" plays in the background. Celia breaks the kiss and asks Ross to talk to her, but not in a conventional way—she wants him to talk dirty. Ross is initially confused and embarrassed, unsure of how to respond. Celia insists, pushing him to say something "hot." After much hesitation and panic, Ross blurts out the word "vulva," which seems to catch both of them off guard. The scene ends with an awkward yet humorous moment of Ross's failed attempt at being provocative.

background: Scene: Lydia's Hospital Room, Joey is helping Lydia go through labor, a nurse is now present in her room as well.

lines.dialogue: Breathe, breathe, breathe...
Oh, no.
Ew! What is that? Something exploded!
It's just her water breaking. Calm down, will you?
(panicked) Water breaking, what do you mean? What's that, water breaking?
(to Joey) Breathe, breathe, breathe.

summary: In this scene, Lydia is in her hospital room during labor, with Joey and a nurse present. The nurse calmly instructs Lydia to breathe, but Lydia expresses distress. Joey, who seems inexperienced and panicked, reacts dramatically to what he thinks is an explosion, only to be informed by the nurse that it's Lydia's water breaking. The nurse then tries to calm Joey down by telling him to breathe as well.

background: Scene: A Restaurant, Monica is breaking the news to Alan.

lines.dialogue: Wow.
I'm, I'm really sorry.
Yeah, I'm sorry too. But, I gotta tell you, I am a little relieved.
Relieved?
Yeah, well, I had a great time with you.. I just can't stand your friends.

summary: In this scene, Monica is informing Alan about a significant decision or situation, expressing her regret. Alan, while also expressing his own regret, reveals that he feels a sense of relief. When Monica questions this, Alan clarifies that although he enjoyed his time with her, he cannot tolerate her friends. The scene highlights a conflict between personal compatibility and social dynamics.

background: Scene: An Emergency Room, Chandler and Joey are leading Ross in.

lines.dialogue: (to the receptionist)'Scuse me.
(holds up her hand—she is on the phone) It says to call this number if you're not completely satisfied with this candy bar. Well, I'm not completely satisfied.
Listen, it's kind of an emergency. Well, I guess you know that, or we'd be in the predicament room. (The receptionist glares at him.)
(on phone) Hold on. (To Chandler) Fill these out, sit over there. (Tosses him some forms.)
(jumping to his feet) Look, I don't wanna make any trouble, okay, but I'm in a lot of pain here, alright? My face is dented.
Well, you'll have to wait your turn.
Well, how long do you think it'll be?
(sarcastic) Any minute now.
Hey, this- (she gives him a look and the guys back off) Heyy...

summary: In this scene, Ross is in significant pain and has a dented face, likely due to an injury. Chandler and Joey are trying to get him medical attention at the emergency room. However, the receptionist is preoccupied with a phone call about a candy bar and is unhelpful. Chandler tries to explain the urgency, but the receptionist dismisses them, handing over forms and instructing them to wait. Ross, frustrated and in pain, tries to speak up, but the receptionist's dismissive attitude forces them to back off. The scene highlights the frustrating bureaucracy and lack of empathy in a healthcare setting.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, everyone is there.

lines.dialogue: I can't believe you would actually say that. I would much rather be Mr.Peanut than Mr.Salty.
No way! Mr.Salty is a sailor, all right, he's got to be, like, thetoughest snack there is.
I don't know, you don't wanna mess with corn nuts. They're craaazy.
(looking out of the window) Oh my God. You guys! You gotta come see this! There's some creep out there with a telescope!
I can't believe it! He's looking right at us!
Oh, that is so sick.
I feel violated. And not in a good way.
How can people do that?... (All but Phoebe walk away from the window in disgust.) Oh, you guys, look! Ugly Naked Guy got gravity boots!

summary: In this scene, the group is gathered at Monica and Rachel's apartment. Chandler and Joey are debating over who would win in a fight between Mr. Peanut and Mr. Salty, with Ross adding that corn nuts are also a formidable opponent. The conversation takes a sudden turn when Monica notices a creepy guy outside with a telescope, spying on them. Everyone reacts with shock and disgust, feeling violated. Phoebe, however, diverts their attention by pointing out that Ugly Naked Guy has acquired gravity boots.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Rachel and Ross are eating Chinese.

lines.dialogue: Marcel. Bring me the rice, c'mon. Bring me the rice, c'mon. Good boy. Good boy. C'mere, gimme the rice. (Marcel brings the rice) Thank you, good boy. Well, I see he's finally mastered the difference between 'bring me the' and 'pee in the'. (Rachel ignores him) 'Bring me the' and- Rach?
What?
Hi.
Oh, I'm sorry. Oh, this is so stupid! I mean, I gave Barry up, right? I should be happy for them! I am, I'm happy for them.
Really.
No. Oh, oh, I guess it would be different if I were- with somebody.
Whoah, uh, what happened to, uh, 'Forget relationships! I'm done with men!' The whole, uh, penis embargo?

Oh, I don't know. I guess it's not about no guys, it's about the right guy, y'know? I mean, with Barry, it was safe and it was easy, but there was no heat. With Paolo, that's all there was, was heat! And it was just this raw, animal, sexual...
Wait-wait. I, I got it. I was there.
Well, I mean, do you think you can ever have both? Y'know? Someone who's like, who's like your best friend, but then also can make your toes curl?
Yes. Yes. Yes! Yes, I really do! In fact, it's funny, very often, someone who you wouldn't think could-could curl your toes, might just be the one who...
Hi.
...Gets interrupted. Hi!
Hi, how was the movie?
Wonderful!
So good!
Suck-fest.
Toootal chick-flick.
I-I'm sorry it wasn't one of those movies with, like, y'know, guns and bombs and, like, buses going really fast...
Hey, I don't need violence to enjoy a movie. Just so long as there's a little nudity.
There was nudity!
I meant female nudity. Alright? I don't need to see Lou Grant frolicking.
Hugh! Hugh Grant!
Alright, I've gotta go. C'mon, Marcel! C'mon! We're gonna go take a bath. Yes we are, aren't we? Yes, we are.
They're still just friends, right?
(To Marcel) And I will see you tomorrow!
That's right, you're gonna spend tomorrow at Aunt Rachel's, aren't you.
Oh, hang on, hang on. Does Aunt Monica get a say in this?
'Pwease, Aunt Monica, pwease?' Oh, unclench. You're not even gonna be there.

summary:
In this scene, Ross is at Monica and Rachel's apartment with Rachel, eating Chinese food. Ross is training his monkey, Marcel, to bring him rice, which Marcel successfully does. Ross then makes a joke about Marcel finally understanding the difference between "bring me the" and "pee in the," but Rachel is distracted and not paying attention.

Rachel reveals that she's upset because she's thinking about Barry's engagement, even though she knows she should be happy for him. Ross points out that Rachel had previously declared she was done with men, but Rachel explains that she now realizes it's not about avoiding relationships altogether, but about finding the right person. She expresses her desire for someone who can be both her best friend and someone who can make her feel passionate. Ross agrees that it's possible to find someone who can fulfill both roles.

Meanwhile, Monica, Phoebe, Joey, and Chandler return from watching a movie. Joey complains that the movie was a "suck-fest" and a "chick-flick," while Monica and Phoebe defend it. Joey jokes that he doesn't need violence in a movie, just some nudity, specifically female nudity.

Ross announces that he has to leave to give Marcel a bath and mentions that Marcel will be spending the next day with Rachel. Monica playfully objects, but Ross dismisses her, saying she won't even be there. The scene ends with Ross leaving with Marcel, and Rachel saying goodbye to Marcel.

background: Scene: Central Perk, Joey enters, amongst snickers from the gang.

lines.dialogue: So I guess you all saw it.
Saw what?
No, we were just laughing. You know, how laughter can be infectious.

summary: In the scene, Joey enters Central Perk and is met with snickers from the gang. He assumes they saw something embarrassing, but Rachel pretends not to know what he's referring to. Phoebe playfully deflects by saying they were just laughing because laughter is contagious. The scene ends with an awkward yet humorous moment as Joey is left unsure whether they are genuinely laughing at him or not.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, the girls are all there, discussing their bad luck with men.

lines.dialogue: Ok, ok, Roger was creepy, but he was nothing compared to Pete Carney.
Which one was Pete Carney?
Pete the Weeper? Remember that guy who used to cry every time we had sex. (imitating) "Was it good for you?"
Yeah, well, I'll take a little crying any day over Howard-the-"I-win"-guy. (imitating) "I win! I win!" I went out with the guy for two months—I didn't get to win once.
How did we end up with these jerks? We're good people!
I don't know. Maybe we're some kinda magnets.
I know I am. That's why I can't wear a digital watch.
There's more beer, right?
Oh! You know my friend Abby who shaves her head? She said that if you want to break the bad boyfriend cycle, you can do like a cleansing ritual.
Pheebes, this woman is voluntarily bald.
Yeah. So, we can do it tomorrow night, you guys. It's Valentine's Day. It's perfect.
Ok, well, what kind of ritual?
Ok. We can, um, we can burn the stuff they gave us.
Or?
Or...or we can chant and dance around naked, you know, with sticks.
Burning's good.
Burning's good. Yeah, I got stuff to burn.

summary:
In this scene, Rachel, Monica, and Phoebe are hanging out at Monica and Rachel's apartment, lamenting their bad luck with men. Rachel mentions two particularly bad exes: Roger, who was creepy, and Pete Carney, who would cry during sex. Monica counters with her own terrible ex, Howard, who would always declare himself the winner in their relationship. They both express confusion over why they keep attracting such problematic partners.

Phoebe then suggests that they might be "magnets" for bad relationships, and she shares a story about her friend Abby, who shaves her head and believes in cleansing rituals to break the cycle of bad boyfriends. Phoebe proposes that they perform a ritual on Valentine's Day, either by burning the gifts from their exes or by chanting and dancing naked with sticks. Monica and Rachel agree that burning is a good idea, and they seem open to the ritual to break their bad luck with men.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, the gang is all sitting around the table.

lines.dialogue: Oh, look look look. The last candle's about to burn out. 10, 9, 8, 7... (time lapse)... negative 46, negative 47, negative 48.... (someone blows it out, the room gets completely dark)
Thank you.
Thanks.
Kinda... spooky without any lights.
(does a maniacal laugh) Bwah-hah-hah!
OK, guys, guys? I have the definitive one. Mwwwooooo-hah-hah...
Oh.. oh... oh.
Hey Ross. This probably isn't the best time to bring it up, but you have to throw a party for Monica.

summary: In this scene, the gang is gathered at Monica and Rachel's apartment. Phoebe notices the last candle is about to burn out and starts a countdown, which quickly turns into negative numbers. Someone blows out the candle, plunging the room into darkness. Ross and Phoebe thank whoever blew it out. Ross comments on how spooky it is without any lights, and Joey responds with a maniacal laugh. Ross then attempts his own spooky laugh but stumbles over it. Joey takes the opportunity to remind Ross that he needs to throw a party for Monica, despite the awkward timing.

background: Scene: The Hospital, Monica and Rachel are waiting for the doctors to arrive.   They enter and are played by Noah Wyle and George Clooney.

lines.dialogue: ..you add a pinch of saffron, it makes all the difference.
Okay, errrr, Monica?
Yes? (jumping as Rachel punches her arm) ..yes, she is.
Hi, this is my friend Rachel.
Hi.
(Smiling) Hi, err Rachel. I'm Dr.Mitchell.
(Smiling even more and attempting to take over) And I'm his friend, Dr.Rosen.
Aren't you a little cute to be a doctor?
Excuse me?
I meant er, (struggling to concentrate) young, young, I meant young, young to be a doctor. Oh good, Rach.
Thank you.
Right.

summary:
In this scene, Monica and Rachel are waiting in a hospital for the arrival of two doctors, Dr. Mitchell and Dr. Rosen, who are played by Noah Wyle and George Clooney. The scene begins with Dr. Mitchell making a comment about cooking, mentioning that adding saffron makes a significant difference.

When Dr. Mitchell addresses Monica, she initially responds, but Rachel playfully punches her arm, causing Monica to confirm that she is indeed Monica. Rachel then introduces herself as Monica's friend, and Monica does the same, introducing Rachel.

Dr. Mitchell introduces himself as "Dr. Mitchell," and Dr. Rosen, trying to assert himself, introduces himself as "Dr. Rosen," emphasizing that he is Dr. Mitchell's friend.

Rachel, flustered, makes a comment about Dr. Rosen being "cute" to be a doctor, which she awkwardly tries to rephrase as "young." Monica and Rachel then exchange brief, confused responses, ending the scene with a mix of awkwardness and humor.

background: Scene: Central Perk, Phoebe is coaching Chandler on how to break up with Janice.

lines.dialogue: Ok, you can do this. It's just like pulling off a Band-aid. Just do it really fast, and then the wound is exposed.
Janice. Hi, Janice. Ok, here we go. I don't think we should go out anymore. Janice.
All right. Well, there you go. (she gets extremely wound up, and begins to try and calm herself down) Stop it, stop it, stop it.

summary: In the scene, Phoebe is coaching Chandler on how to break up with Janice in a straightforward manner, likening it to quickly pulling off a Band-Aid. Chandler attempts to deliver the breakup message, but Janice reacts by becoming extremely emotional and then trying to calm herself down. The scene ends with Janice acknowledging the breakup, but her emotional state remains intense.

background: Scene: Nana's house, Ross, Mrs. Geller and Aunt Lillian are going through clothes.

lines.dialogue: I thought it was gonna be a closed casket.
Well, that doesn't mean she can't look nice!
Sweetie, you think you can get in there?
(sarcastic) I don't see why not.
Here's my retainer!

summary: In this scene, Ross and Mrs. Geller (presumably Ross's mother) are at Nana's house, going through clothes. Ross seems surprised that they are focusing on how Nana will look, given that it was supposed to be a closed casket funeral. Mrs. Geller insists that Nana should still look nice, showing her attention to detail and respect for Nana's appearance. Ross, in a sarcastic tone, playfully comments on his ability to fit into the situation, even mentioning his retainer, adding a light-hearted moment to the otherwise somber context.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, everyone is there but Rachel.

lines.dialogue: Look, if she's talking to it, I just think that I should get some belly time too. Not that I believe any of this.

Oh, I believe it. I think the baby can totally hear everything. I can show you. Look, this will seem a little weird, but you put your head inside this turkey, and then we'll all talk, and you'll hear everything we say.
I'd just like to say that I'm totally behind this experiment. In fact, I'd very much like to butter your head.
Hey, Rach, did you make your money?
No, not even close. Forget Vail, forget seeing my family, forget shoop, shoop, shoop.
Rach, here's your mail.
Thanks, you can just put it on the table.
(insistently) No, here's your mail.
Thanks, you can just put it on the table.
(gives her an envelope) Would you just open it?
Oh my god, oh, you guys are great.
We all chipped in.
(to Monica) We did?
(to Joey) You owe me 20 bucks.
Thank you. Thank you so much!
(hands Chandler a bag) Chandler, here you go, got your traditional Thanksgiving feast, you got your tomato soup, your grilled cheese fixin's, and your family size bag of Funyuns.
Wait, wait, Chandler, this is what you're havin' for Thanksgiving dinner? What, what, what is it with you and this holiday?
All right, I'm nine years old.
Oh, I hate this story.

We just finished this magnificent Thanksgiving dinner. I have--and I remember this part vividly--a mouthful of pumpkin pie, and this is the moment my parents choose to tell me they're getting divorced.
Oh my god.
Yes. It's very difficult to appreciate a Thanksgiving dinner once you've seen it in reverse.

summary:
In this scene, the group is gathered at Monica and Rachel's apartment, with the exception of Rachel. The conversation begins with Ross expressing his desire to bond with the baby, even though he doesn't believe in the mystical beliefs Phoebe holds about the baby's ability to hear. Phoebe suggests a quirky experiment involving a turkey to demonstrate her point, which Chandler humorously supports by offering to butter Ross's head.

Meanwhile, Monica is insistent that Rachel open an envelope she has received, which turns out to be a collection of money from the group to help Rachel with her financial troubles. Rachel is deeply grateful for their support.

The scene shifts to Chandler receiving his traditional Thanksgiving meal, which consists of tomato soup, grilled cheese, and Funyuns. Rachel is surprised by this and questions Chandler about his choice of meal. Chandler then shares a deeply personal story about his childhood, revealing that his parents announced their divorce to him during a Thanksgiving dinner when he was nine years old. This traumatic memory has left him with a negative association with the holiday, explaining his unconventional meal choice.

The scene ends with a mix of humor and emotional depth, highlighting the group's support for each other and Chandler's vulnerability.

background: Scene: Central Perk. Phoebe is there with Roger.

lines.dialogue: What's wrong, sweetie?
Nothing, nothing.
Aaaah, what's wrong, c'mon. (Pats his leg. She lies down and rests her head in his lap)
It's, I mean, it's nothing, I'm fine. It's my friends. They-they have a liking problem with you. In that, um, they don't.
Oh. They don't.
But they don't see all the wonderfulness that I see. They don't see all the good stuff and all the sweet stuff. They just think you're a little...
What?
Intense and creepy.
Oh.
But I don't. Me, Phoebe.
Well, I'm not I'm not at all surprised they feel that way.
You're not? See, that's why you're so great!

Actually it's, it's quite, y'know, typical behaviour when you have this kind of dysfunctional group dynamic. Y'know, this kind of co-dependant, emotionally stunted, sitting in your stupid coffee house with your stupid big cups which, I'm sorry, might as well have nipples on them, and you're like all 'Oh, define me! Define me! Love me, I need love!'.

summary: In this scene, Phoebe is at Central Perk with Roger, who is aware that her friends don't like him. Phoebe tries to reassure Roger by emphasizing that she sees the good in him, despite her friends finding him "intense and creepy." Roger, however, dismisses her friends' concerns and criticizes their group dynamic, describing them as co-dependent and emotionally stunted, while also mocking their coffee habits. The scene highlights the tension between Roger and Phoebe's friends, as well as Roger's self-awareness (or lack thereof) about his own behavior.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Monica and Rachel are there. Monica is just finishing cleaning the windows.

lines.dialogue: Windows are clean, candels are lit. Uh, belt's to tight, gotta change the belt. Did I turn the fish? (goes over to the kitchen to check on the dinner) No, cause I made lasagne. (to Rachel) Am I out of control?
Just a touch. Mon, I don't understand. I mean, you've been dating this guy since like, what... his midterms? I mean, why all the sudden are you so... Oh.
What?
Could tonight be the Night?
I don't know. Look he's a great guy and I love being with him but... you know. Things happen, and they happen. You don't plan these things.
So, did you shave your legs?
Yeah.
A-ha!

summary: In this scene, Monica and Rachel are in their apartment. Monica has just finished cleaning the windows and is checking on dinner, which is lasagna. Monica seems slightly anxious and asks Rachel if she's "out of control." Rachel teases her, suggesting that Monica might be preparing for something significant, possibly a romantic night with her boyfriend. Monica admits she doesn't know if tonight will be "the night," but Rachel playfully points out that Monica has shaved her legs, implying that she's anticipating something special. The scene ends with a lighthearted moment between the two friends.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's continued from earlier.

lines.dialogue: Ok, Paulo, why don't you just go get dressed, and then you be on your way, ok, bye-bye.
Rachel, how did this happen?
I don't know, I just kinda ran into him last night.
Where?
At his apartment. Is this juice?
Whoa, whoa. And the fact that you dumped him because he hit on Phoebe?
Oh God, I know I'm a pathetic loser.
Honey, you're not pathetic, you're sad.
People do stupid things when they're upset.
My god, if I had a nickel for every guy I wish I hadn't--but this is about your horrible mistake.
Hi. Sorry we're late but we were--well, there was touching.
Hey, hey Ross.
Hey, Paulo. What are you doing here?
I do Raquel.
(to Rachel) So, uh, he's back.
Yeah, he's back. Is that a problem?
No, not a problem.
Good! I'm glad it's not a problem.
Ok, you're gonna have to not touch my ass.
Well, in spite of the yummy bagels and palpable tension, I've got pants that need to be altered.
Hey, Chandler, when you see Frankie, tell him Joey Tribbiani says hello. He'll know what it means.
Are you sure he's gonna be able to crack that code?
You know it's funny, the last time Paulo was here, my hair was so much shorter and cuter.
All right. Ok, but, but you have to promise that you will not be all like control-y and bossy and Monica about it.
I promise.
All right. Now some of you are gonna get cut, and some of you aren't. But I promise none of you are gonna feel a thing.

summary:
In this scene, Rachel is dealing with the unexpected return of Paolo, the man she previously dumped for hitting on Phoebe. Monica is shocked and tries to understand how Rachel ended up back with Paolo, while Rachel admits she doesn't know how it happened. Joey points out the irony of Rachel dumping Paolo for hitting on Phoebe, only to get back together with him. The group is generally supportive but also a bit critical of Rachel's decision.

Ross enters the scene, surprised to see Paolo, and Rachel brushes off any concerns Ross might have about her getting back together with Paolo. The tension between the characters is evident, with Phoebe making a joke about Paolo's tendency to touch her inappropriately. Chandler tries to lighten the mood by making a joke about needing to alter his pants, and Joey adds a cryptic message for Frankie through Chandler.

Monica reflects on how much has changed since Paolo was last around, and Phoebe warns Monica not to be too controlling about the situation. The scene ends with Phoebe making a cryptic statement about some people getting "cut" and promising that no one will feel anything, leaving the audience curious about what she means.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, the next morning.

lines.dialogue: You know, I think I was sixteen.
Please, just a little bit off the back.
I'm still on "no".
(poking her head in from her bedroom) Uh, morning. Do you guys think you could close your eyes for just a sec?
No no no no no, (grabs his pants) I'm not fallin' for that again.
What's goin' on?
Well, I sorta did a stupid thing last night.
What stupid thing did you do?
Bon giorno tutti!
Ewww!

summary: In this scene, the group is gathered at Monica and Rachel's apartment the morning after a night of events. Joey starts a conversation about being sixteen, possibly referencing a haircut or something else. Monica asks for a small trim, and Phoebe is still against whatever is being discussed. Rachel enters from her bedroom, asking everyone to close their eyes for a moment, which Joey refuses to do, having been tricked before. Phoebe is curious about what's happening, and Rachel admits to doing something stupid the previous night. Before Rachel can explain, Paolo enters, greeting everyone with "Bon giorno tutti!" (Good morning, everyone!), which elicits a disgusted reaction from Phoebe. The scene ends with this unexpected arrival and Phoebe's reaction.

background: Scene: Central Perk, the gang is all there.

lines.dialogue: Rachel, do you have any muffins left?
Yeah, I forget which ones.
Oh, you're busy, that's ok, I'll get it. Anybody else want one?
No thanks.
Oh, you're losin' your apron here, let me get it. There you go. (Ties it back up for her)
(to Julie) Thank you. (under her breath to Chandler) What a bitch.
Oh, listen you guys. I have this friend at Bloomingdales who's quitting tomorrow and he wants to abuse his discount. So, anyone want to come with me and take advantage of it?
I can't, I have to take my grandmother to the vet.
Ok, um, I'll go with you.
Great.
(enters) Hi, honey.
Hey, sweetums.
Hello to the rest.
Hi!
Monica what're you doin'? You can't go shopping with her? What about Rachel?
It's gonna be a problem, isn't it?
Come on, you're going to Bloomingdales with Julie? That's like cheating on Rachel in her house of worship.
But I'm--
Monica, she will kill you. She will kill you like a dog in the street.
So, uh, Jules tells me you guys are going shopping tomorrow?
Yeah, uh, it's actually not that big a deal.
It's a big deal to me. This is great, Monica. I really appreciate this.
You're welcome.
Woof, woof.

summary: In this scene, the gang is gathered at Central Perk. Julie asks Rachel for a muffin, and Rachel, seemingly distracted, lets Julie take care of it herself. Rachel mutters under her breath about Julie being a "bitch." Julie then invites the group to go shopping at Bloomingdales with her, offering to take advantage of a friend's employee discount. Monica agrees to go with her, which causes tension among the group, especially with Rachel. Joey and Chandler express their disapproval, with Chandler comparing it to cheating on Rachel in her "house of worship." Phoebe even warns Monica that Rachel might react violently. Ross, who enters later, seems appreciative of Monica's decision to go shopping with Julie, but the underlying tension between the friends is evident.

background: Scene: Mr. Ratstatter's (RTST) office. Monica is there about a job.

lines.dialogue: This is a nice resume. Nice, nice, nice. Muy impressivo.
So, Mr. Rastatter, what exactly does this job entail? The ad wasn't too clear.
Mockolate.
I'm sorry?
Mockolate. It's a completely synthetic chocolate substitute.
Ohh.

summary: In the scene, Monica (MNCA) is in Mr. Ratstatter's (RTST) office for a job interview. Mr. Ratstatter compliments Monica's resume, calling it "muy impressivo." Monica asks about the job's responsibilities, as the ad was unclear. Mr. Ratstatter responds by mentioning "Mockolate," a synthetic chocolate substitute. Monica seems intrigued but also slightly confused by the term. The scene ends with this brief exchange, leaving the specifics of the job and the nature of "Mockolate" unexplored.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Monica is getting ready to go to Joey's premiere and Phoebe is still on hold.

lines.dialogue: (to Phoebe) Here you go. You can wear this. (hands her a sweater)
Thanks!
Uh-huh.

Okay. (on phone) Ooh, I'm setting the phone down. (does so) But I'm still here! Just don't go anywhere I'm still here. (starts to put on the sweater) Don't-don't switch or anything, 'cause I'm, I'm right here. (She has pulled the sweater over her head, but her head is stuck in a sleeve.) Just one sec. One sec! One second!! (She is now frantically trying to get the sweater on, as Monica returns from the bathroom.) Wait! One second! Just...
Phoebe?
What?! Monica, I'm scared!!
All right. Honey, that's-that's a sleeve. Okay?
Yeah.
And! We also have speaker phone. (She turns on the speaker phone.)
Please, stay on the line. Your call is important to us.
Okay, wait, you gotta hang up 'cause we're gonna be late.
Thank you for your patience, you're the next caller.
Yes!! Yes!! I'm the next caller! You were gonna have me hang up.
(entering, carrying the chick and duck) Hey! Can you take a duck and a chick to the theatre?
Of course not.
No.
Okay. I just wanted them to hear it from somebody else.

summary: In this scene, Monica is preparing to go to Joey's premiere, and Phoebe is on hold on the phone. Monica offers Phoebe a sweater to wear, which Phoebe struggles to put on, getting her head stuck in a sleeve. Monica helps her by pointing out that it's just a sleeve and turns on the speakerphone, where the hold voice confirms that Phoebe is the next caller. Chandler enters, asking if they can take the chick and duck to the theater, but both Monica and Phoebe refuse. The scene ends with Chandler acknowledging their rejection.

background: Scene: Monica's bedroom, Phoebe is trying to relax her.

lines.dialogue: ( in a soothing voice) Relax every muscle in your body. Listen to the plinky-plunky music. Okay, now close you eyes, and think of a happy place. Okay, tell me your happy place.
Richard's living room, drinking wine.
All right. No, no, no, not a Richard thing, just put down the glass. And get out!
I'm sorry, but that's my happy place.
Well, okay, fine, use my happy place. Okay, I'm just gonna, I have to ask that you don't move anything.
All right, I'll try not to.
Okay, all right, so, your in a meadow, millions of stars in the sky....
Do you think breaking up with him was a huge mistake?
All right, there are no questions in the happy place. Okay, just, the warm breeze, and the moonlight flowing through the trees....
I'll bet he's totally over me, I'll bet he's fine.

All right, betting and wagering of any kind, are, I'm sure, not permitted in the happy place. Okay. Just-just, you know, the-the lovely waterfalls, and the, the trickling fountains. And the-the calming sounds of the babbling brook....
Okay, this isn't working. I'm still awake and now I have to pee.

summary: In this scene, Phoebe is trying to help Monica relax by guiding her to visualize a happy place. However, Monica's mind keeps drifting back to her ex-boyfriend Richard, and she repeatedly brings up thoughts and questions about him, disrupting the relaxation process. Despite Phoebe's attempts to redirect her focus to a serene meadow with stars, warm breezes, and calming sounds, Monica's anxiety about Richard persists. The scene ends with Monica admitting that the relaxation attempt isn't working and that she needs to use the bathroom.

background: Scene: Central Perk, Chandler, Monica, Janice are sitting on the couch, and Phoebe is sitting next to them in the chair.

lines.dialogue: Well, it's official there are no good movies.
Well, let's go to a bad one and make out. (they start to kiss and lean back into Monica.)
Perhaps, you would like me to turn like this, (turns sideways on the couch) so that you can bunny bump against my back.
(entering) Hey!
Hey.
Hey, man. What's up?
Maybe you can tell me. My agent would like to know why I didn't show up at the audition I didn't know I had today. The first good thing she gets me in weeks. How could you not give me the message?!
Well, I'll tell ya I do enjoy guilt, but, ah, it wasn't me.
Yes, it was! It was him! Uh huh! (they all stare at her) Okay, it was me!
How is it you?

Well, it was just, it was all so crazy, you know. I mean, Chandler was in the closet, counting to 10, and he was up to 7 and I hadn't found a place to hide yet. I-I-I meant to tell you, and I wrote it all down on my hand. See, all of it. (shows him her hand)
Yep, that's my audition.
See, now this is why I keep notepads everywhere.
Yep, and that's why we don't invite you to play.
What is the great tragedy here? You go get yourself another appointment.
Well, Estelle tried, you know. The casting director told her that I missed my chance.
That is unfair. I'll call her and tell her it was totally my fault.
Pheebs, you can't do that. The casting director doesn't talk to friends, she only talks to agents.
What a sad little life she must lead. Okay, ooh (starts dialing) .
What, what are you doing? What are you doing?
No, no, no, I know, I know, ooh. (on the phone in a different voice) 'Hi, this is Katelynn, from Phoebe Buffay's office. Um, is um, Ann there for Phoebe, she'll know what it's about.'
Hang up, hang up. (reaches with his good arm, but Phoebe grabs it and he tries to reach the phone with his other arm but can't because of the sling.)

(on phone) 'Annie! Hi. Listen we got a problem with Joey Tribbiani, apparently he missed his audition. Who did you speak to in my office? Estelle, no, I don't know what I'm going to do with her. No. All right, so your husband leaves and burns down the apartment, the world does not stop.'
Is anybody else scared?

(on phone) 'Right, well look, um, if Joey loses this audition, that is it for Estelle. I don't care! Annie you are a doll, what time can you see him?' (to Monica) I need a pen. (Chandler hands her one, but she needs something to right on, so she tilts Chandler's head over and writes on the back of his neck)
Get the woman a pad! Get the woman a pad! A pad! A pad!
Oh, now you want a pad.

summary:
In this scene, the group is hanging out at Central Perk. Chandler complains about the lack of good movies, and Janice suggests they go to a bad one and make out, much to Monica's annoyance. Joey enters, upset because he missed an important audition he didn't know about, blaming Chandler for not passing on the message. Phoebe confesses that she was the one who forgot to tell Joey, explaining that she was distracted by Chandler hiding in the closet.

Joey is frustrated, but Janice dismissively tells him to just get another appointment. Phoebe, feeling guilty, decides to call the casting director directly to fix the situation, despite Joey's protests. She pretends to be from Phoebe Buffay's office and starts negotiating with the casting director, even writing notes on Chandler's neck when she needs a surface to write on. The scene ends with Chandler demanding a notepad, and Monica teasing him about it.

background: Scene: Phoebe's, she is coming home. She turns on the lights, and sits down on the couch.

lines.dialogue: (hiding under a pile of clothes) Hi. (She jumps up screaming.) Wait, no! Just put the mail down. It's-it's me!
Okay. Whoa, sorry. Why were you just like all in the dark?
Oh well, um, your, your laundry just smelled so good, that I thought I'd curl up in it. Is that all right?
Oh, yeah, sure. So, how was your day?
Oh, well just probably the worst one since I've been alive.
What umm, what happened?
Umm, Alice ah, she ah, called it off.
Oh no. Did umm, did she say why?
Uh, no, not really, just that I was too young, y'know, but I don't see how I could all of the sudden be too young, 'cause I'm older than I was when we first got together.
Yeah, yeah, no, I don't, I don't know. But, y'know what, maybe it's just all for the best?
Yeah, if the best is like unbelievable pain!
Oh, sweetie, oh. (hugs him)

Y'know, I just was finally happy y'know. For the first time in my life! After my Dad left me, and then, and then getting arrested for stealing those birds, and then, and then the whole punctured lung thing! I can, it's still really hard to take deep breaths in cold weather, but with Alice all that stuff kinda went away. And now it's, and now it's gone and I don't know why!
Uh, well I can tell you why. It's, it's because of me. But, y'know what, I only did it because I love you. Okay?
What?
Umm, well I, I kinda had a little chat with Alice, and I sort of made her see why you two shouldn't be together, y'know. And you're gonna see it to, one day, you really, really will.
Wait a minute, wait, this is because of you?
Okay.
Well, you, wait no, my Mother didn't want us to be together, but the worst thing she ever did was tie me to the porch.
Okay, but.
Wait, y'know what, I-I came to you because I thought you'd understand! Oh no!! Y'know, I would storm out of here right now if-if I had some money, or a place to go...

summary:
In this scene, Phoebe returns home and is startled to find Frank hiding under a pile of clothes. Frank explains that he was feeling down and found comfort in her laundry. Phoebe then learns that Frank's girlfriend, Alice, has broken up with him, citing his youth as the reason. Frank expresses his deep pain and confusion over the breakup, as he felt truly happy for the first time in his life with Alice.

Phoebe, however, reveals that she is the reason behind the breakup. She admits to having a conversation with Alice, where she convinced her that Frank and Alice shouldn't be together. Frank is shocked and upset by this revelation, feeling betrayed by Phoebe, whom he thought would understand his situation. He expresses his frustration and desire to leave, but lacks the means to do so. The scene ends with Frank's emotional turmoil and Phoebe's admission of her role in his heartbreak.

background: Scene: Central Perk, Phoebe's singing, Vince is also there.

lines.dialogue: (singing) “Crazy underwear, creepin' up my butt. (Jason enters) Crazy underwear, always in a rut. Crazy under- (sees Jason) -wear...” (In her head) Oh No! What is he doing here? All right, just keep playing, just keep playing. You'll get through this; you'll be fine. (She tries to continue the song, but she has lost the ability to pronounce words, and the lyrics come out as gibberish.) (giving up on the song) Okay, thank you. And, as always no one talk to me after the show.
(going up to her) Hey. I was...
Hey!
I was passin' by and I saw that you were playing tonight, it's kinda cool seeing you up there. (kisses her)
(running over) Whoa! Hey-hey! What's going on here? Who is this guy?
I don't know, he just started kissing me. Get him! Get him, Vince!
What?!
What?!

Yeah, okay, I've-I've been dating both of you, and it's been really horrible. 'Cause y'know it's been a lot of fun, for me. Umm, but I-I like you both, and I, and I didn't know how to chose, so... I'm sorry, I'm just, I'm terrible, I'm a terrible person. I'm terrible.
Phoebe, Phoebe relax, it's okay. I mean we never said this was exclusive.
Yeah, and neither did we. Give yourself a break.
Really?!
Yeah. I mean y'know, we haven't been going out that long. Come on, we haven't even slept together yet. Huh.
You haven't?
You have?
Well, this is none of my business. (starts to walk away)
(to Phoebe) I-I can't believe this! You-you've slept with him?!
Well, I made you a candle light dinner in the park.
Y'know Phoebe, I'm gonna make this real easy for you. (walks out)
(to Vince) Well, that could've been really awkward.
You made him a candle light dinner in the park?
Yeah, but I-I-I-I can do that for you, I'm gonna do that for you.
Uh yeah, I can't believe I ever went out with somebody who would actually have an open flame in the middle of a wooden area. (walks out)

summary:
In this scene, Phoebe is performing her quirky song at Central Perk when Jason, another one of her boyfriends, unexpectedly enters. She is visibly flustered and struggles to continue singing, eventually giving up. Jason approaches her, and they share a kiss, which catches the attention of Vince, her other boyfriend.

Vince confronts the situation, and Phoebe is forced to admit that she has been dating both of them, which she finds "really horrible" but also "a lot of fun." Both Vince and Jason initially take the news surprisingly well, as neither relationship was exclusive. However, the conversation quickly turns awkward when it's revealed that Phoebe has slept with Vince but not with Jason, who had only received a candlelight dinner in the park.

Jason is upset by this revelation and leaves, while Vince, still processing the idea of Phoebe having an open flame in a wooden area, also walks out. Phoebe is left to reflect on the awkward situation, realizing that juggling two boyfriends was more complicated than she anticipated.

background: Scene: A bar, Chandler is entering.

lines.dialogue: Hey, Mon.
Hey-hey-hey. You wanna hear something that sucks.
Do I ever.
Chris says they're closing down the bar.
No way!
Yeah, apparently they're turning it into some kinda coffee place.
Just coffee! Where are we gonna hang out now?
Got me.
(to bartender) Can I get a beer.
Hey, did you pick a roommate?
You betcha!
Is it the Italian guy?
Um-mm, yeah right!
He's so cute.
Oh yes, and that's what I want a roommate that I can walk around with and be referred to as the funny one.
Oh look, the pool table's free. Rack 'em up. I'll be back in just a minute. Get ready for me to whip your butt.
Okay, but after that, we're shootin' some pool.

(sitting at a table with some of her friends) (to waitress) Oh, um, no, no, no, no excuse me, hello. Hi. My friend ordered an onion, not an olive, and uh I ordered a rum and Diet Coke, which I don't think this is.
I am so sorry.
That's all right. (to her friends) I mean hard is it to get a couple drinks right, huh?
Well, I would like to propose a toast to the woman, who in one year from today, become Mrs. Dr. Barry Farber DDS
Ummm, I think it's time to see the ring again. (holds her hand out and they all scream)
Oh, isn't it exciting, I mean it's like having a boyfriend for life.
Yeah, I know.
What?

Oh, I don't know. Well maybe it's just the idea of Barry for the rest of my life. I don't know I think I feel like I need to have one last fling, y'know, just to sorta get it out of my system. (Chandler is listening in very intensely)
Rachel stop!
You're so bad!
I'm serious, I really, I think I need just to have some...meaningless, sex y'know, with the next guy that I see.
Excuse, I seem to have dropped my ball.
Yeah, so?
(picks it up) And now I've picked it up again. (walks over to Monica.)
Oh my God, I went to high school with her. (to Rachel) Rachel! Hi!
Monica! Look! Hi! What do ya think? (shows her, her ring)
Oh my God, you can't even see where the Titanic hit it.
Yes, his name is Barry, he's a doctor, thank you very much.
Awww, just like you always wanted. Congratulations
Thank you. So how-how 'bout you, are-are you seeing anybody?
Aww, not right now.
Oh, but that's okay.
I know.
Yeah.
So, I'll get-get back to my friend.
Oh, yeah, sure, sure, sure, sure. (points at Chandler, who holds up the cue ball as a 'Remember me?' thing) Listen, can we please have lunch the next time I'm in the city?
Oh, that'd be great.
Okay!
Thanks.
Bye!
Bye! (to Chandler) Ten bucks says, I never see that woman again in my life.

summary:
In this scene, Chandler enters a bar where Monica is already present. Monica shares the disappointing news that the bar is closing down and will be turned into a coffee place. Chandler expresses his frustration about losing their hangout spot. Monica then asks Chandler if he has picked a roommate, and Chandler dismisses the idea of choosing an Italian guy, jokingly referring to the stereotype of being the "funny one."

Meanwhile, Rachel is sitting with her friends, discussing her engagement to Barry. Her friends propose a toast to her upcoming marriage, but Rachel seems uncertain and contemplates having a "last fling" before settling down. Chandler overhears this and awkwardly interjects, pretending to drop and pick up a pool ball.

Monica and Rachel recognize each other from high school, and they exchange pleasantries, with Rachel showing off her engagement ring. Monica congratulates her but privately bets Chandler that she won't see Rachel again. The scene ends with a mix of lighthearted banter and underlying tension about the changes in their lives.

background: Scene: The Moondance Diner, Pete is talking to Monica about the restaurant.

lines.dialogue: So? I mean have you thought about it?
Okay. Here's the thing.
Oh no, not the thing. I hate the thing. What's the thing?
I can't do it. I'm sorry, I wish I could, but umm, see you have these feelings for me....
Wait, wait, wait, wait, that's-that's what you're worried about? If that's the problem, we've got no problem.
Huh?
No! Look, I was gonna tell you this over dinner, but I met somebody else. On my trip.
Oh?

Her name's Ann, she's a journalist. Ahh, we met on the plane. She asked me if she could finish off my peanuts, I thought she said something else, we had a big laugh. Yeah, I just, I mean I got, I got tired of waiting.
Oh, that's great! I mean I'm-I'm sorry, but I'm so happy for you. And now I can work for you!
I guess you can.
Oh my God! Oh, this is incredible! Ohh! (she rolls over and kisses him on the cheek) All right, y'know what? I'm just gonna roll right into that office and-and quit!
All right.
Okay. (she gets ready to go) Can you give me a little push?
Yeah, sure. Good luck!

(rolling towards the office) I'm quitting!! Woo-hoo! (She rolls through a doorway and out of sight. We then hear a big crash, and see Monica roll past the door the other way.) I'm okay!! I'm all right!!
(to Pete) Wow! That's exciting, you went to Japan, made up a woman.
What?
I'm just saying, this woman, I mean she's fictitious. No?
Why would you say that?

'Cause you're still into Monica. So you told her there was somebody else so she would agree to work with you, so 'cause you figure oh if you spent a lot of time together, maybe something might happen, and...
You're good. You're good!
Yeah, no, I'm fairly intuitive and psychic. It's a substantial gift.
Listen, can you promise me that you won't tell her though?
Absolutely, oh I promise. Tell her what?
Thanks a lot.
No I'm serious. I mean I'm intuitive, but my memory sucks.

summary: In the scene, Pete is trying to convince Monica to work for him at the Moondance Diner. Monica initially declines, citing Pete's feelings for her as a reason. To alleviate her concerns, Pete claims he has moved on and is now dating a woman named Ann, a journalist he met on his trip. Monica is relieved and excited to accept the job offer. Meanwhile, Phoebe, who overhears the conversation, suspects that Ann is a made-up character, implying that Pete is still interested in Monica and created Ann to manipulate the situation. Pete asks Phoebe not to reveal his secret, but Phoebe playfully agrees without fully committing. The scene ends with Monica enthusiastically quitting her current job and Phoebe's humorous skepticism about Pete's story.

background: Scene: Monica's bedroom, she's in bed with Richard.

lines.dialogue: So we can be friends who sleep together.
Absolutely, this will just be something we do, like racquetball.
Sounds smart and healthy to me. So um, just out of curiosity, um, do you currently have any other racquetball buddies?
Just your dad. (pause) Although that's actually racquetball. You know I-I do have a blind date with my sister's neighbour next Tuesday.
Oh.
You want me to cancel it?
No! (pushes him) No!
Okay.
'Cause if you do that means you'd be cancelling it for me, and we're just friends.
Exactly. (pushes her back)

summary: In this scene, Monica and Richard are discussing their arrangement of being "friends who sleep together." Monica initially presents it as a casual, no-strings-attached relationship, comparing it to playing racquetball. Richard agrees, but Monica, out of curiosity, asks if he has any other "racquetball buddies." Richard humorously mentions that he only plays racquetball with Monica's dad, but he does have a blind date scheduled with his sister's neighbor. Monica, despite her initial reaction, insists that Richard should not cancel the date, emphasizing that their arrangement is purely platonic. The scene ends with both of them reaffirming their commitment to keeping their relationship as friends.

background: Scene: Monica and Rachel's balcony, Ross and Phoebe are grilling some burgers and hot dogs.

lines.dialogue: (joining them) Hey.
Hey! How long until Pete's fight?
Oh, about five minutes. Right now they're interviewing his opponent. Apparently he trains by going to Iran and pulling the arms off thieves.
Hot dog?
Four, please. (Ross looks at her) I'm really nervous. (Ross gives her the four dogs) Thank you. (she grabs four buns, and heads back inside)
So Ross, how umm, how did it go with Bonnie?
What? Oh! I gotta tell you, I-I wasn't expecting to like her at all, I mean I actually wasn't expecting to like anyone right now, but she's really terrific.
Ohh, that's too bad!
No, I-I'm saying I liked her.
Yeah, y'know what, there are other fish in the sea.
Pheebs, I think she's great. Okay? We're going out again.
Okay, I hear you! Are you capable of talking about any thing else?
(joining them) Hey! Which one's my turkey burger?
Ahh, the one next to my foot. Sorry.
(sticking his head out the window) Hey, the fight's starting!
Okay, we'll be right in. (to Chandler) So ah, did your boss try to slap you again today?
Nine times! Okay, I had to put on lotion! But, it's gonna be okay, because as of tomorrow I'm conducting an experiment, and if all goes as planned, my butt will be smack free.
(sticking his head out the window) Fight's over!

summary:
In this scene, Monica, Ross, Phoebe, and Chandler are on Monica and Rachel's balcony, where Ross and Phoebe are grilling burgers and hot dogs. Monica is anxious about Pete's upcoming fight, which is starting soon. Ross offers her some hot dogs to calm her nerves, and she takes four, indicating her stress.

Phoebe brings up Ross's date with Bonnie, and Ross expresses that he unexpectedly liked her and plans to see her again. Phoebe seems to be implying that Ross should move on from Rachel, but Ross insists he genuinely likes Bonnie.

Chandler joins the group, asking for his turkey burger, and Ross teases him about his boss trying to slap him. Chandler reveals that his boss slapped him nine times that day, but he has a plan to avoid it in the future.

Meanwhile, Joey, who is inside, alerts them that the fight has started and then quickly announces that it's over. The scene ends with the group reacting to the quick conclusion of the fight.

background: Scene: Central Perk, Monica is entering, Phoebe is already there.

lines.dialogue: Hey!
Hey!
Hey, guess what I'm doing tonight.
What?
I'm checking out the restaurant with Pete.
Ohh, Monica, I am so excited for you.
I know.
Ooh, I have to tell you something.
What?
But I can't tell you.
Okay, but wouldn't it be easier if you had to tell me something that you could tell me.
Well, sure in a perfect world. But, no, I promised I wouldn't tell, and I swore to like all my gods.
Okay. Does it have to do with Ross and Rachel?
No.
Does it have to do with Joey?
No.
Does it have to do with-with Chandler and that sock that he keeps by his bed?
No, but let's come back to that later!

summary: In this scene, Monica enters Central Perk and greets Phoebe. Monica excitedly tells Phoebe that she is going to check out a restaurant with Pete later that evening. Phoebe expresses her excitement for Monica. However, Phoebe then reveals that she has something to tell Monica but can't because she made a promise not to. Monica tries to guess what the secret might be, asking if it involves Ross and Rachel, Joey, or even Chandler's mysterious sock. Phoebe denies all of these guesses but hints that they might revisit the topic of Chandler's sock later. The scene ends with Phoebe sticking to her promise not to reveal her secret.

background: Scene: Pete's apartment, Pete and Monica are coming back from a date.

lines.dialogue: Lights. (The lights turn on, once again they're too bright.) Uh, romantic lights. (The lights dim.)
Ooh, nice.
So ah, there was this thing I wanted to talk to you about.
Oh, right! I completely forgot about that.
Well ah, I've been doing a lot of thinking, and I look at my life...
Yeah?
And I feel like I've conquered the business world, and I feel like I've conquered the intellectual world, and now I-I have the most beautiful woman in the world.
Wow.
There's one thing missing.
What's that?
It's time for me to conquer the physical world.
Okay. (not sure of herself)
Monica, I want to become (pause) the Ultimate Fighting Champion.
You wanna what?!
I want to become the Ultimate Fighting Champion! It's the most intense physical competition in the world, it's banned in 49 states!
What are you talking about?
Okay, my trainer, Ho Chi, is teaching me a combination of Gee Koon Doe and Brazilian street fighting, I've even had my own octagon training ring designed.
And I suppose you used a ring designer for that.
Yeah. Monica, I want you there in the front row when I win. I want you close enough to smell the blood. What do you think?
My parents will be so happy.
